questions.question: Question 1: Salivary amylase is activated by which of the following ions?
questions.explanation:
Salivary amylase is activated by Cl-. Human salivary and pancreatic amylases are activated by chloride (Cl–). They have optimum 
activities near-neutral pH (7.4). They hydrolyze internal 1:4 linkages but spare 1:6 linkages and 
terminal 1:4 linkages in starch.

questions.question: Question 2: Where does the digestion of disaccharides occur?
questions.explanation:
Digestion of disaccharides occurs in the small intestine. The enzymes maltase, sucrase, isomaltase, lactase, and trehalase are located in the 
enterocytes covering the intestinal microvilli brush border. The disaccharides are digested into 
their constituent monosaccharides as they come in contact with these enterocytes.

questions.question: Question 3: The mechanism by which glucose is absorbed in the intestine is:
questions.explanation:
Glucose is absorbed in the intestine by secondary active transport. On the basolateral side, there is active transport of sodium ions out of the cell into the interstitial 
fluid. This depletes sodium inside the cell. Because of this Na+ concentration difference, more 
Na+ binds to the SGLT on the luminal side. This increases the affinity of SGLT for glucose and 
glucose binds to it. Then, both the Na+ and glucose are transported together to the interior of the cell. Thus, glucose 
is absorbed in the intestine by secondary active transport. The energy for glucose transport is 
provided indirectly, by the active transport of Na+ out of the cell. The glucose moves out of the 
cell into the blood across the basolateral membrane by facilitated diffusion mediated via GLUT. 586 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following is a true statement?

options.a: Fructose is absorbed in the intestine by secondary active transport
options.b: SGLT2 is involved in absorption of monosaccharide in intestine
options.c: GLUT2 is involved in transport of glucose from enterocyte into interstitium
options.d: GLUT4 is responsible for basal glucose uptake in many organs

questions.explanation:
GLUT2 is involved in the transport of glucose from the enterocyte into the interstitium (or out of 
the enterocytes). The image below shows the function of GLUT 2 on enterocytes. Option A: Fructose absorption is through facilitated diffusion from the intestinal lumen into the 
enterocyte by GLUT5 and out of the enterocytes into the interstitium by GLUT2. Option B: SGLT1 is involved in the absorption of glucose into the enterocyte. SGLT2 is responsible 
for glucose transport out of the renal tubules. Option D: GLUT1 is responsible for basal glucose uptake in many organs. 587 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 5: Which of the following is the main enzyme involved in the hydrolysis of 1,6 linkage of 
starch?
questions.explanation:
The main enzyme involved in the hydrolysis of 1,6 linkage of starch is isomaltase. Both salivary and the pancreatic  -amylases hydrolyze internal 1:4 linkages but spare 1:6 
linkages and terminal 1:4 linkages of starch.

questions.question: Question 6: What is chymotrypsinogen?
questions.explanation:
Chymotrypsinogen is a zymogen. çymogens (proenzymes) are inactive precursors of the enzymes. Most of the peptidases 
(proteases) are present in the form of proenzymes. Trypsinogen, chymotrypsinogen, proelastase, 
procarboxypeptidase A, procarboxypeptidase B are zymogens.

questions.question: Question 7: Which of the following processes converts trypsinogen to trypsin?

options.c: Removal of a few amino acids

questions.explanation:
Trypsinogen is converted to trypsin by the removal of a few amino acids. All proenzymes are converted to their active form by selective proteolysis (removal of a few amino 
acids). Enterokinase cleaves trypsinogen to yield active trypsin. It is located on the brush border of 
duodenal enterocytes. 588 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 8: Which of the following protects the normal pancreas from autodigestion?
questions.explanation:
The synthesis and secretion of proteases as catalytically inactive proenzymes protect the normal 
pancreas from autodigestion. All the protease proenzymes present in the pancreatic juice get converted to their active form only 
in the small intestinal lumen (site of action). If proenzymes get activated in the pancreas (site of origin), they can digest the entire pancreas 
within a few hours, giving rise to the condition called acute pancreatitis.

questions.question: Question 9: Which of the following is not an endopeptidase?
questions.explanation:
Carboxypeptidase is an exopeptidase, not endopeptidase. Peptidases (proteases) are of two types: • Endopeptidases - they act at interior peptide bonds in the peptide molecules. Ex- pepsin, trypsin, 
chymotrypsin, elastase. • Exopeptidases - they hydrolyze the amino acids at the carboxyl ends of the polypeptides, one at a 
time. Ex- carboxypeptidase, aminopeptidase.

questions.question: Question 10: Peptide transporter 1 is involved in the absorption of which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Peptide transporter 1 (PepT1) is involved in the absorption of the dipeptide. The dipeptides and tripeptides are transported along with H+ into enterocytes by a system known 
as peptide transporter 1 (PepT1). 589 
Sold by @itachibot These peptides undergo intracellular hydrolysis to release amino acids. These amino acids are 
absorbed into the circulation from the basolateral membrane via basolateral amino acid 
transporter. H+ moves out of the cell via Na+-H+ exchanger on the luminal side.

questions.question: Question 11: Which of the following is passively absorbed in the gut?
questions.explanation:
Lipids are passively absorbed in the gut. The products of lipid digestion (monoglycerides and free fatty acids) are incorporated into 
micelles that are formed by bile salts and diffuse across the intestinal epithelium. Short and 
medium-chain fatty acids can directly diffuse across the intestinal epithelium. Note: Recent evidence suggests that specific carrier proteins (membrane transporters) may be 
involved in the transport of long-chain fatty acids.

questions.question:
Question 12: Short-chain fatty acids produced by bacteria are maximally absorbed in which part of the 
intestine?
questions.explanation:
Short-chain fatty acids produced by bacteria are absorbed maximally in the colon by secondary 
active transport. Almost all the iron absorption occurs in the duodenum. Vitamin B12 is absorbed in the ileum. Folate is absorbed in the upper small intestine (duodenum and jejunum). Maximum water absorption takes place in the jejunum.

questions.question: Question 13: Which of the following is not a function of short-chain fatty acids in the colon?

options.a: Trophic effect on the colonic epithelial cells

questions.explanation:
590 
Sold by @itachibot Short-chain fatty acids (2–5-carbon) in the colon promote the absorption of Na+, not secretion. Short-chain fatty acids (SCFA) in the colon are formed by the action of colonic bacteria on 
complex carbohydrates, resistant starches, and other components of the dietary fiber i.e the 
material that escapes digestion in the upper gastrointestinal tract and enters the colon. Functions: • Exert a trophic effect on the colonic epithelial cells • Combat inflammation • Helps in maintaining acid-base equilibrium

questions.question: Question 14: Which of the following patients is most likely to have a major electrolyte imbalance?

options.a: A patient with duodenal resection due to a primary tumor
options.b: A patient who underwent jejunal resection due to an obstruction
options.c: A patient with ileal resection due to recurrent Crohn's disease
options.d: A patient with sigmoid resection due to a recurrent fistula

questions.explanation:
The resection of jejunum leads to major electrolyte imbalance because most of the fluid and 
electrolyte reabsorption occurs in this segment. The maximum water absorption takes place in the jejunum. The amount of water absorbed in the intestines follows this order: Jejunum > Ileum > Colon. Almost all the iron absorption occurs in the duodenum. Vitamin B12 is absorbed in the ileum. Folate is absorbed in the upper small intestine (duodenum and jejunum).

questions.question: Question 15: What is the amount of fluid absorbed in the intestine in a day?
questions.explanation:
The amount of fluid absorbed in the intestine in a day is around 8L. About 2L of ingested water and 7L of various secretions enter the gastrointestinal tract. Out of 
this, the majority (8800 mL) is absorbed in the small intestine and colon. The small remaining 
volume that is not absorbed (100–200 mL) is excreted in feces.

questions.question: Question 16: Which of the following is not absorbed in the colon?
questions.explanation:
K+ is not absorbed in the colon. It is secreted in the rectal fluid. Electrolytes (Na+, Cl-), short-chain fatty acids (acetate, propionate, butyrate), and water are 
absorbed in the colon. 591 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 17: Which of the following is false about vitamin absorption?

options.a: Fat-soluble vitamin digestion needs cholesterol esterase
options.b: Vitamin B12 is absorbed in ileum
options.c: Folate is absorbed by carriers that are Na+ cotransporters
options.d: Most vitamins are absorbed in upper small intestine

questions.explanation:
Folate and vitamin B12 absorption is Na+-independent. The remaining water-soluble vitamins—thiamin, riboflavin, niacin, pyridoxine, pantothenate, 
biotin, and ascorbic acid are absorbed by carriers that are Na+ cotransporters. Option A: Fat-soluble vitamins are ingested in the form of esters. Digestion needs hydrolysis by 
cholesterol esterase and absorbed after incorporating into micelles. Options B and D: Most vitamins are absorbed in the upper small intestine, but vitamin B12 is 
absorbed in the ileum. Vitamin B12 binds to intrinsic factor, a protein secreted by the parietal 
cells of the stomach. This complex is absorbed across the ileal mucosa.

questions.question:
Question 18: A patient with anemia is prescribed iron tablets. The absorption of the supplement is likely to 
take place in which part of the intestine?
questions.explanation:
Almost all the iron absorption occurs in the duodenum. Most of the iron in the diet is in the ferric (Fe3+) form, whereas it is the ferrous (Fe2+) form that 
is absorbed. Note: Carbohydrates, proteins, lipids are absorbed throughout the length of the small intestine. 
Bile acids are present throughout the small intestine, but active absorption occurs only in the 
ileum, and active absorbtion of folate occurs in the upper small intestine (duodenum and 
jejunum).

questions.question: Question 19: Which of the following stimulates ferritin synthesis?
questions.explanation:
Elemental iron stimulates ferritin synthesis. 592 
Sold by @itachibot It synthesizes ferritin by causing the release of a cytoplasmic protein that binds to a specific 
region in the ferritin mRNA. This disruption activates ferritin mRNA and results in its translation. Hepcidin binds to ferroportin and triggers its internalization and degradation. This results in 
decreased iron absorption and decreased circulating iron levels which reduces ferritin synthesis. Note: Ferritin sequesters Fe2+, a potentially toxic molecule.

questions.question: Question 20: Which of the following is inhibited by hepcidin?
questions.explanation:
Hepcidin inhibits iron absorption. It is named for its originally described property as a hepatocellular protein with bactericidal 
activities. Iron metabolism is regulated by hepcidin, a protein and acute phase reactant produced by the 
liver. It binds to ferroportin and degrades it. This inhibits the transfer of iron from the enterocyte 
to the plasma via ferroportin. As a result, iron becomes trapped within the duodenal cells 
(enterocytes) in the form of mucosal ferritin and is lost in feces when these cells are shed off. 593 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 21: While prescribing iron to a patient with iron deficiency anemia, which of the following would 
you recommend to increase its absorption?
questions.explanation:
Ascorbic acid is given with iron to increase its absorption. Ascorbic acid (vitamin C) forms soluble complexes with iron and reduces iron from the ferric to 
the ferrous state, thereby enhancing iron absorption. Option A: Milk decreases iron absorption. Option C: Gastric secretions increase iron absorption by dissolving the iron and allowing it to 
form soluble complexes with ascorbic and other substances. This helps in its reduction to the 
Fe2+ form. Antacid decreases the absorption of iron. Option D: Tannins (present in tea), phytates, phosphates, and oxalates form insoluble complexes 
with iron and lower its absorption.

questions.question: Question 22: All of the following regulates intestinal absorption of iron except:

options.c: State of iron stores in the body
options.d: State of erythropoiesis in bone marrow

questions.explanation: Intestinal absorption of iron is not regulated by the daily loss of iron. The intestinal absorption of iron is regulated by three factors: • Recent dietary intake of iron • State of the iron stores in the body • State of erythropoiesis in the bone marrow

questions.question: Question 23: What is the end product after the action of colonic bacteria on dietary fiber?
questions.explanation:
594 
Sold by @itachibot The action of colonic bacteria on dietary fiber would give butyrate. Colonic bacteria act on complex carbohydrates, resistant starches, and dietary fiber to form 
short-chain fatty acids such as acetate, propionate, and butyrate. SCFAs are 2–5-carbon weak acids that have an average normal concentration of about 80 mmol/L 
in the lumen.

questions.question: Question 24: Where are the cell bodies of the orexinergic neurons are present in a patient?
questions.explanation:
Cell bodies of orexigenic neurons are present in the lateral hypothalamic area. Orexin stimulates 
food intake. Role of hypothalamus in gastrointestinal and feeding regulation: • Hunger center - lateral hypothalamic area • Satiety center - ventromedial nuclei • Feeding reflexes such as licking the lips and swallowing - mammillary bodies. Note: The arcuate nucleus contains at least two different types of neurons that when stimulated 
lead to either increased or decreased appetite.

questions.question:
Question 25: In a patient who is fasting, the stomach releases a hormone that increases food intake. 
Identify the hormone secreted.
questions.explanation:
The hormone secreted by the stomach that increases food intake is ghrelin. Ghrelin, the hunger hormone is produced by the endocrine cells in the oxyntic glands of the 
stomach. It increases food intake. Its levels increase during fasting, peaks just before the 
beginning of food intake, or when the person is expecting a meal. The levels fall within 1 hour of 
the start of feeding. Option A: Orexin is synthesized from lateral hypothalamic neurons. It increases food intake. Option B: Leptin is produced by adipocytes. It decreases food intake. Option C: CCK is released from the small intestine. It decreases food intake.

questions.question: Question 26: Which of the following is false regarding ghrelin?
questions.explanation:
Ghrelin increases gastric acid secretion. Ghrelin is mainly produced by the endocrine cells in the oxyntic gland area of the stomach. It is 
also secreted by the pancreas and adrenal glands. Functions: • Increases appetite/food intake (orexigenic) • Inhibits leptin release 595 
Sold by @itachibot • Stimulates growth hormone secretion by directly acting on anterior pituitary (ghrelin-growth 
hormone-releasing peptide) • Increases gastric acid secretion and gastrointestinal motility to prepare the body for food intake • Regulates the distribution and rate of use of energy

questions.question: Question 27: What will be the trend of leptin levels in a patient with a BMI of 34 kg/m2.
questions.explanation:
A patient with a BMI of 34 kg/m2 is categorized as obese. Leptin levels are high in obesity. Leptin is an appetite-suppressing hormone synthesized from adipocytes. The larger the fat stores, 
the more leptin is released into the blood. Leptin resistance in obese persons may be due to its failure to cross the blood-brain barrier and 
reach the hypothalamus to serve its appetite-suppressing function. Note: A recent study has indicated that triglycerides which are elevated in obesity, inhibit the 
transport of leptin across the blood-brain barrier.

questions.question: Question 28: Which of the following is not a dietary fiber?
questions.explanation:
Gum is the best answer among the given options. Even though all of the given options are dietary 
fibers, the consumption of gums through diet is very low and hence, it is the best answer. Dietary fibers consist of both soluble and insoluble forms and include lignin, pectin, inulin, 
cellulose, hemicellulose, etc. Advantages of fibers: • Forms bulk of the stool and reduces stool transit time • Reduces incidence of carcinoma colon, DM, CAD, diverticulitis

questions.question: Question 29: All of the following have a significant role in lipid digestion except:
questions.explanation:
Lingual lipases are of little quantitative significance for lipid digestion other than in the setting of 
pancreatic insufficiency. Lingual lipase is secreted by Ebner glands on the dorsal surface of the tongue in some species, and 
the stomach also secretes lipase. Digestion of Lipids • Pancreatic lipase is the most important enzyme involved in lipid digestion. The main products of 
its action are FFA and 2-monoglycerides (2-monoacylglycerols) • Colipase is an accessory factor secreted in the pancreatic juice that helps to stabilize pancreatic 
lipase in an active conformation 596 
Sold by @itachibot • Bile acids emulsify the insoluble lipids and make them reach the surface of the mucosal cells. 
Bile acids also activate another pancreatic lipase called cholesterol esterase • Cholesterol esterase hydrolyzes cholesterol esters, esters of fat-soluble vitamins, phospholipids, 
and triglycerides

questions.question: Question 30: Following complete ileal and partial jejunal resection, the patient is most likely to have
questions.explanation:
After complete ileal and partial jejunal resection, the patient is likely to have vitamin B12 
deficiency. Vitamin B12 is absorbed in the ileum. Vitamin B12 binds to intrinsic factor, a protein secreted by 
the parietal cells of the stomach, and the complex is absorbed across the ileal mucosa. Hence after 
ileal resection, there is impaired absorption of vitamin B12.

questions.question: Question 31: Transport molecule for Fe2+ into the enterocytes is
questions.explanation:
Transport of Fe2+ into the enterocytes occurs via divalent metal transporter 1 (DMT1), through an 
active transport process. Protein DMT-1 (Divalent Metal Transporter-1) is expressed on the apical surface of enterocytes in 
the initial part of the duodenum. DMT-1 is not specific to iron & transports other substances 
like zinc, copper, cobalt & manganese.

questions.question: Question 32: Which part of the liver stores vitamin A?
questions.explanation:
Vitamin A is stored in the liver perisinusoidal stellate (Ito) cells as retinyl ester (retinol palmitate). 597 
Sold by @itachibot Kupffer cells, also known as stellate macrophages and Kupffer-Borowicz cells; are specialized 
macrophages located in the liver that form part of the mononuclear phagocyte system. These are 
present, lining the walls of the sinusoids, not the perisinusoidal space (Space of Disse). 598 
Sold by @itachibot GI Peristalsis and Motility
